questions.text: Which of the following produces action through serpentine receptor?
questions.solution:
Serpentine receptors means G protein coupled receptors. Named so because, a single polypeptide chain traverses through the biological membrane and serves its purpose. Glucagon acts via GPCR with cAMP pathway. Glycine acts via chloride ion channel, Prolactin acts via JAK-STAT and thyroxine via nuclear receptors.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 55.

questions.text: Full activation of the parasympathetic system is likely to produce which of the following effects?
questions.solution:
Parasympathetic discharge causes bronchial and intestinal smooth muscle contraction and bradycardia.

Thermoregulatory(eccrine) sweat glands are innervated by sympathetic cholinergic fibers, not parasympathetic.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 112.

questions.text: A group of volunteers are involved in a phase 1 clinical trial of a new autonomic drug. When administered by intravenous bolus, the blood pressure increases. When given orally for 1 week, the blood pressure decreases. Which of the following standard agents does the new drug most resemble?
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 611.

questions.text: Use of felbamate is limited due to which of the following adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Felbamate:

  • GABA agonist and NMDA antagonist
  • Used only in refractory seizures (Never a first line drug for any type of seizures)
  • Causes severe aplastic anemia and hepatotoxicity

Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no. 399.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain and stiffness in his wrists and knees. The stiffness is worse first thing in the morning. A blood test confirms rheumatoid arthritis. You advise a short course of steroids. Which one of the following is the most potent anti-inflammatory steroid?
questions.solution:
Of the drugs listed, cortisol has the lowest and dexamethasone the highest anti-inflammatory activity.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 313.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is most likely to block ADP receptors and prevent platelet aggregation?
questions.solution:
Platelet aggregation is stimulated by many compounds, including ADP, thromboxane A2, fibrin, and serotonin. Clopidogrel, along with ticlopidine, blocks ADP receptors and prevent platelet activation. Prostacyclin (PGI2) from endothelial cells is a naturally occurring compound that inhibits platelet aggregation by stimulating PGI2 receptors. Aspiring inhibits the synthesis of thromboxane A2. Abciximab is a monoclonal antibody targeted to the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor which inhibits aggregation. Montelukast blocks leukotriene receptors and is used in asthma.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 678.

choices.text: Warfarin should be continued until the third trimester
Warfarin should be replaced with aspirin at analgesic doses.
All medications that affect the blood should be discontinued.
Warfarin should be replaced with heparin.

questions.text: A woman who has a mechanical heart valve and who is taking warfarin informs you that she hopes to get pregnant in the near future. What advice should she receive regarding her antithrombotic medication during the anticipated pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Discontinuing warfarin is appropriate during pregnancy because it is a known teratogen that causes bone dysmorphogenesis. The patient will need continued protection against thrombus formation, and heparin (or a related low molecular weight compound) is usually advised, despite the fact that the drug will require parenteral administration and can cause thrombocytopenia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 664-670.

questions.text: Which of the following agent is the most suitable for treatment of pulmonary hypertension?
questions.solution:
PGE2 and PGI2 are vasodilators whereas PGF2α and TXA2 are vasoconstrictors. Epoprostenol is a PGI2 analogue and it can be used for pulmonary hypertension

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 207.

questions.text: Multiple drug resistance is transferred through:
questions.solution:
Gene transfer (infectious resistance)

The resistance causing gene is passed from one organism to the other; is called horizontal transfer of resistance. Rapid spread of resistance can occur by this mechanism and high level resistance to several antibiotics(multidrug resistance) can be acquired concurrently.

  1. Conjugation Sexual contact through the formation of a bridge or sex pilus is common among gram-negative bacilli of the same or another species. This may involve chromosomal or extrachromosomal(plasmid) DNA. The gene carrying the 'resistance' or 'R' factor is transferred only if another 'resistance transfer factor'(RTF) is also present. Conjugation frequently occurs in the colon where a large variety of gram-negative bacilli come in close contact. Even nonpathogenic organisms may transfer R factor to pathogenic organisms, which may become widespread by contamination of food or water. Chloramphenicol resistance of typhoid bacilli, streptomycin resistance of E. coli and many others have been traced to this mechanism.
  2. Transduction It is the transfer of gene carrying resistance through the agency of a bacteriophage. The R factor is taken up by the phage and delivered to another bacterium which it infects. Certain instances of penicillin, erythromycin and chloramphenicol resistance have been found to be phage mediated.
  3. Transformation A resistant bacterium may release the resistance carrying DNA into the medium and this may be imbibed by another sensitive organism-becoming unresponsive to the drug. This mechanism is probably not clinically significant.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 743.

questions.text: A 4 yr old baby is brought to the casualty with an unknown tablet poisoning which was to be used for bacterial dysentery as per parent's history. The child had vomiting for more than 24 hrs and had diarrhoea with green stools. She is lethargic and an ashen color skin. Also has hypothermia, hypotension and abdominal distention. Which drug is most likely to produce these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Gray baby syndrome

It occurred when high doses(~100 mg/kg) were given prophylactically to neonates, especially premature.

The baby stopped feeding, vomited, became hypotonic and hypothermic, abdomen distended, respiration became irregular; an ashen gray cyanosis developed in many, followed by cardiovascular collapse and death. Blood lactic acid was raised.

It occurs because of inability of the newborn to adequately metabolize and excrete chloramphenicol. Chloramphenicol should be avoided in neonates.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 791.

choices.text: Absorption of digoxin is delayed by presence of food
Concurrent food intake may severely reduce rate of absorption of phenytoin
Presence of food enhances absorption of hydrochlorothiazide
Anti-malarial drug halofantrine is more extensively absorbed if taken with food

questions.text: Presence of food might be expected to interfere with drug absorption by slowing gastric emptying or by altering the degree if ionization of the drug in the stomach. Which of the following statements is not the correct example?
questions.solution:
Presence of food in stomach delays absorption of digoxin and digitoxin

Oral absorption of halofantrine is variable and enhanced with food

Food ingested has not been found to affect absorption of hydrochlorothiazide

Absorption of phenytoin is slow mainly due to its poor solubility and not due to food intake.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 440.

choices.text: Blocking transport of choline into neurons
Blocking release of acetylcholine from storage vesicles

questions.text: Botulinum toxin causes paralysis by
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin

Botulinum toxin A and B are highly potent exotoxins produced by Clostridium botulinum that are responsible for 'botulism' (a type of food poisoning).

These neurotoxic proteins cause long-lasting loss of cholinergic transmission by interacting with axonal proteins involved in exocytotic release of ACh.

Localized injection of minute quantity of botulinum toxin A(BOTOX) or its haemagglutinin complex(DYSPORT) can be used in the treatment of a number of spastic and other neurological conditions like blepharospasm, spastic cerebral palsy, strabismus, spasmodic torticollis, nystagmus, hemifacial spasm, post stroke spasticity, spasmodic dysphonia, axillary hyperhydrosis, etc. which are due to overactivity of cholinergic nerves.

It is being employed popularly as beauty treatment for removal of age-related facial wrinkles. However, incorrect injection or overdose can be dangerous; ptosis, diplopia, facial swelling, dry mouth, dysphagia, dysarthria, muscular weakness and even respiratory paralysis has occurred.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 110-111.

questions.text:
A new drug was given to 25 normal subjects in a phase 1 clinical trial. The cardiovascular effects are summarized in the table below:

Which one of the following drugs the new experimental drug most resemble?
questions.solution:
The investigational agent caused a marked increase in systolic and diastolic pressures and a moderate increase in pulse pressure (from 40 to 60 mm Hg). These changes suggest a strong alpha effect on vessels and an increase in stroke volume, a β-agonist action in the heart. The heart rate increased significantly, reflecting a β response. Note that the stroke volume also increased (cardiac output divided by heart rate-from 70.2 to 81.7 mL). The drug behaves most like a mixed α and β agonist.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 142-143.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for augmenting the action of SSRI
questions.solution:
Drugs used for augmentation:

  1. Mirtazapine (Choice)
  2. Buprapion
  3. Lithium
  4. T3 (Contra indicated with lofepramine)
  5. L-tryptophan
  6. Pindolol.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 490.

questions.text: A newborn girl exhibited ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension as a result of genetic deficiency of 21α-hydroxylase activity. Treatment consisted of fluid and salt replacement and hydrocortisone administration. In this type of adrenal hyperplasia in which there is excess production of cortisol precursors, which of the following describes the primary therapeutic effect of glucocorticoid administration?
questions.solution:
A 21α-hydroxylase deficiency prevents normal synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone and causes accumulation of cortisol precursors (Figure 39-2). The hypothalamic-pituitary system responds to the abnormally low levels of cortisol by increasing ACTH release. High levels of ACTH induce adrenal hyperplasia and excess production of adrenal androgens, which can cause virilization of females and prepubertal males. Glucocorticoid is administered to replace the missing mineralocorticoid and glucocorticoid activity and to suppress ACTH release, which removes the stimulus for excess adrenal androgen production.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 314.

choices.text: Drug B displaces warfarin from plasma proteins; drug C displaces warfarin from tissue-binding sites
Drug B inhibits hepatic metabolism of warfarin; drug C displaces drug B from tissue-binding sites
Drug B stimulates hepatic metabolism of warfarin; drug C displaces warfarin from plasma protein
Drug B increases renal clearance of warfarin

questions.text: The above graph shows the plasma concentration of free warfarin as a function of time for a patient who was treated with 2 other agents, drugs B and C, on a daily basis at constant dosage starting at the times shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the observed changes in warfarin concentration?
questions.solution:
A drug that increases metabolism (clearance) of the anticoagulant lowers the steady state plasma concentration (both free and bound forms), whereas one that displaces the anticoagulant increases the plasma level of the free form only until elimination of the drug has again lowered it to the steadystate level.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 669-670.

choices.text: Direct stimulation of cardiac contractile force

questions.text: One effect that theophylline, nitroglycerin, isoproterenol, and histamine have in common is
questions.solution:
Theophylline does not ordinarily cause headache or postural hypotension. Nitroglycerin does not cause direct cardiac stimulation but does evoke a compensatory sympathetic reflex. Histamine does not cause bronchodilation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 244-587.

questions.text: Drug not causing this adverse reaction on ECG is
questions.solution:
This is Torsades de pointes due to QT prolongation. Drugs causing QT prolongation includes

“HIGH CLASS RAM TAKES CARE OF FORD ENGINE’S HEART”

High → antiHistaminic

Class → antiCholinergics,

R → Risperidone

A → antiArrhythmics

M → Mefloquine

Takes → TCA’s

Care → Chloroquine

Ford → Fluoroquinolones

Engine → Erythromycin

HEART → Haloperidol, QT- Prolongation

Magnesium is the drug of choice in treatment of Torsades de pointes.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no. 689.

questions.text: Polypeptide antibiotic bacitracin acts on:
questions.solution:
Other drugs acting on bacterial cell wall:

  • Beta lactam antibiotics
  • Fosfomycin
  • Bacitracin
  • Glycopeptide antibiotics (Vancomycin, Teicoplanin)
  • Cycloserine

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 809.

choices.text: Absorption is increased when taken with food
It causes tooth discoloration in developing fetus itself

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding tetracyclines?
questions.solution:
Absorption is impaired when taken with food leading to incomplete absorption

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 786.

questions.text: New drug study and development can be done by:
questions.solution:
Molecular modelling allows new drug designing and development by the process of conceptualizing for the performance of required function based on essential characteristics, including idealized structure and protein properties.

Molecular modelling is a science or art of representing molecular structure numerically and stimulating their behavior with the equation of quantum and classical physics.

Neo pharmacy refers to new drugs

Pharmacolibrary means storage of database of drugs that is required for development of new drugs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 89.

questions.text: Organophosphates act by inhibiting the enzyme acetylcholinesterase. What type of enzyme inhibitors are they?
questions.solution:
Both organophosphates and carbamates cause competitive inhibition of AchE. But organophosphates are irreversible, and most carbamates are reversible.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 116.

questions.text: Sodium valproate in a patient with bipolar disorder can cause
questions.solution:
Sodium valproate adverse effects:

V - Vomiting

A - Alopecia

L - Liver enzymes elevated

P - Pancytopenia, Pancreatitis

R - Retention of fat

O - Oedema

A - Appetite decreased

T - Tremors

E - Enzyme inducer

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 444.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy with failure to thrive and metabolic disturbances was found to have an inactivating mutation in the gene that encodes the growth hormone receptor. Which of the following drugs is most likely to improve his metabolic function and promote his growth?
questions.solution:
This child's condition is due to the inability of GH to stimulate the production of insulin-like growth factors, the ultimate mediators of GH effects. Mecasermin, a combination of recombinant IGF-1 and the binding protein that protects IGF-1 from immediate destruction, will help correct the IGF deficiency. Because of the inactive GH receptors, somatropin will not be effective.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 259.

choices.text: Feminization of the external genitalia of male offspring
Infertility and development of vaginal cancer in female offspring

questions.text: Diethylstilbestrol(DES) should never be used in pregnant women because it is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a nonsteroidal estrogen agonist. Several decades ago, misguided use of the drug in pregnant women appears to have resulted in fetal damage that predisposed female offspring to infertility and a rare form of vaginal cancer. For this reason, the drug should be avoided in pregnant women. Other estrogenic drugs do not appear to have these effects. Although estrogens do increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis, this is not the reason why DES should be avoided.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology by Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page no. 727.

questions.text: A patient develops severe thrombocytopenia in response to treatment with unfractionated heparin and still requires parenteral anticoagulation. The patient is most likely to be treated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Direct thrombin inhibitors such as bivalirudin and argatroban provide parenteral anticoagulation similar to that achieved with heparin, but the direct thrombin inhibitors do not induce formation of antiplatelet antibodies.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 667.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is using an albuterol inhaler for frequent acute episodes of asthma and complains of symptoms that she ascribes to the albuterol. Which of the following is not a recognized action of albuterol?
questions.solution:
Albuterol is a β2-selective receptor agonist, but in moderate to high doses it produces β1 cardiac effects as well as β2-mediated smooth and skeletal muscle effects. It does not cause diuresis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 242.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Digoxin - Xanthopsia (yellow vision)

Sildenafil - Cyanopsia (Blue vision)

Ivabradine - Luminous phenomenon (transiently enhanced brightness in a limited area of the visual field, halos, image decomposition)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 328-560.

questions.text: Which of the following cephalosporin has activity against methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.solution:
Ceftobiprole medocaril

This is another 5th generation cephalosporin active against MRSA and several gram +ive and gram -ive bacteria associated with hospital acquired pneumonia(HAP) as well as with CAP.

Ceftobiprole medocaril is also a prodrug, which is rapidly converted to the active ceftobiprole by type A esterases in humans. It unergoes minimal metabolism and is excreted unchanged by glomerular filtration into urine with a terminal t½ of 3 hours. No accumulatoin occurs on 8 hourly infusion.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 780.

questions.text: Which of the following is a steroid antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Novobiocin - Aminocoumarin antibiotic

Bacitracin - Polypeptide antibiotic

Vancomycin - Glycopeptide antibiotic

Fusidic acid - Steroid antibiotic

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 809.

questions.text: Alcohol is catabolized by which cytochrome enzyme?
questions.solution:
CYP2E1 catalyzes oxidation of alcohol, halothane, formation of NAPBQI from paracetamol. Chronic alcoholics induce this enzyme.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 418.

choices.text: Cause skeletal muscle end plate depolarization

questions.text: Parasympathetic nerve stimulation and slow infusion of bethanechol will each
questions.solution:
Vagus slows the heart. Parasympathetic nerve stimulation does not cause vasodilation (most vessels do not receive parasympathetic innervation), so choice (C) is incorrect. Ganglion cells and the end plate contain nicotinic receptors, which are not affected by bethanechol, a direct-acting muscarinic agonist.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 114-115.

questions.text: Opioids are least effective as analgesic in
questions.solution:
Although nociceptive pain usually is responsive to opioid analgesics, neuropathic pain is typically considered to respond less to opioid analgesics. There is growing perception that, in the face of chronic tissue injury or inflammation, there can be a transition from an inflammatory to a neuropathic pain phenotype. Such transition has important implications for analgesic drug efficacy.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 498.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhea was treated with a drug that successfully restored ovulation and menstruation. Before being given the drug, the woman was carefully questioned about previous mental health problems, which she did not have. She was advised to take the drug orally. Which of the following is most likely to be the drug that was used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Bromocriptine, a dopamine receptor agonist, is used to treat the amenorrhea -galactorrhea syndrome, which is a consequence of hyperprolactinemia. Because of its central dopaminergic effects, the drug should not be used in patients with a history of schizophrenia or other forms of psychotic illness.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 261.

choices.text: Strong family history of breast cancer

questions.text: A 52-year-old postmenopausal patient has evidence of low bone mineral density. She and her physician are considering therapy with raloxifene or a combination of conjugated estrogens and medroxyprogesterone acetate. Which of the following patient characteristics is most likely to lead them to select raloxifene?
questions.solution:
Conjugated estrogens and raloxifene both improve bone mineral density and protect against osteoporosis. The 2 advantages of raloxifene over full estrogen receptor agonists are that raloxifene has antagonist effects in breast tissue and lacks an agonistic effect in endometrium. If a patient’s uterus was removed by surgery, the difference in the endometrial effect is moot. In patients with a strong family history of breast cancer, raloxifene may be a better choice than a full estrogen agonist because it will not further increase the woman’s risk of breast cancer and may even lower her risk.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 338.

choices.text: It increases the formation of plasminogen.
It is less effective than streptokinase when given after a myocardial infarction.
It causes a high incidence of thrombocytopenia.
It may cause bleeding reversible by aminocaproic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the parenteral administration of alteplase?
questions.solution:
Alteplase is thrombolytic (or “fibrinolytic”) because it activates plasminogen, resulting in the increased formation of plasmin. Its efficacy is equivalent to that of streptokinase, but alteplase has the advantage of only activating plasminogen bound to fibrin (clot specific) but not free plasminogen. All thrombolytics can cause bleeding, which may be counteracted to some extent by administration of antifibrinolysins, such as aminocaproic acid.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 674.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child has severe asthma and was hospitalized 5 times between the ages of 7 and 9. He is now receiving outpatient medications that have greatly reduced the frequency of severe attacks. Which of the following is most likely to have adverse effects when used daily over long periods for severe asthma?
questions.solution:
Chronic systemic corticosteroids have important toxicities. If oral corticosteroids must be used, alternate-day therapy is preferred because it interferes less with normal growth and metabolism in children.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 249.

questions.text: Methyldopa is primarily used for:
questions.solution:
Anti-hypertensives safer in pregnancy:

Pregnant HT lady choses DOLO

Pregnant - Prazosin

HT - Hypertension

La - Lazines (Hydralazine)

Dy - Dihydropyridines

Choses - Clonidine

Do - Methyl Dopa

Lo - Labetalol (Drug of choice)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 612.

questions.text: Which of the following beta lactam antibiotics can be safely used in a patient with history of allergy to penicillins?
questions.solution:
Aztreonam:

  • Inhibits PBP-III
  • Can be given IV/IM
  • Structure is similar to ceftazidime
  • Anti-microbial spectrum similar to aminoglycosides

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 781.

questions.text: An 82 yr old hospitalized with creatinine clearance of 25 mL/min has a microbial infection requiring treatment with antibiotics. Which of the following is least likely to require dose adjustments?
questions.solution:
Ceftriaxone is eliminated largely via biliary excretion, and decreases in renal function do not usually require a dose reduction. All of the other antimicrobial drugs listed are eliminated by the kidney, at rates proportional to creatinine clearance, so major dose reductions would be needed in patients with renal dysfunction to avoid toxicity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 778.

questions.text: Therapeutic drug monitoring is not scientific for which of the following agent?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic drug monitoring is not scientific when the agent is a hit and run drug. Ticlopidine is an example of hit and run drug (P2Y12 inhibitor), the action of the drug persists even in the absence of detectable plasma concentration.

Other examples of hit and run drugs include

MGR’s PA

M - MAO inhibitors

G - Guanethidine

R - Reserpine

P - Proton pump inhibitors

A - Aspirin

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 678.

questions.text: Receptor actions of acetyl choline are mimicked by nicotine at which one of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Nicotinic cholinoceptors are found in adrenal medullary chromaffin cells. At the other sites, acetylcholine activates muscarinic cholinoceptors.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 113.

questions.text: All the following are used for myoclonic seizures EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Myoclonic seizures

DOC - Valproic acid

Other drugs

“BENZ TOPPLES”

Ben - Benzodiazepines

Z - Zonisamide

Top - Topiramate

L - Lamotrigene, Levetiracetam

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 449.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with infertility due to obstructed fallopian tubes was undergoing ovulation induction in preparation for in vitro fertilization. After 10 d of treatment with leuprolide, the next step in the procedure is most likely to involve 10-14 d of treatment with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Once the patient’s endogenous gonadotropin production has been inhibited through continuous administration of the GnRH agonist leuprolide, the next step in ovulation induction is the administration of a drug with FSH activity to stimulate follicle maturation. Follitropin is recombinant FSH. The only other drug listed that is used in ovulation induction is hCG, but this is an LH analog.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 263.

choices.text: Morning injections of mixed insulin lispro and insulin aspart
Evening injections of mixed regular insulin and insulin glargine
Morning and evening injections of regular insulin, supplemented by small amounts of NPH insulin at mealtimes
Morning injections of insulin glargine, supplemented by small amounts of insulin lispro at mealtimes

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes wishes to try tight control of her diabetes to improve her long-term prognosis. Which of the following regimens is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Insulin regimens for tight control usually take the form of establishing a basal level of insulin with a small amount of a long acting preparation (eg, insulin glargine) and supplementing the insulin levels, when called for by food intake, with short-acting insulin lispro. Less tight control may be achieved with 2 injections of intermediate-acting insulin per day. Because intake of glucose is mainly during the day, long-acting insulins are usually given in the morning, not at night.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 290.

choices.text: Can be used without monitoring the patient's aPTT
Has a shorter duration of action
Is less likely to have a teratogenic effect
Is more likely to be given intravenously

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents with pain in her left thigh muscle. Duplex ultrasonography indicates the presence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the affected limb. The decision was made to treat this woman with enoxaparin. Relative to unfractionated heparin, enoxaparin
questions.solution:
Enoxaparin is an LMW heparin. LMW heparins have a longer half-life than standard heparin and a more consistent relationship between dose and therapeutic effect. Enoxaparin is given subcutaneously, not intravenously. It is less, not more, likely to cause thrombosis and thrombocytopenia. Neither LMW heparins nor standard heparin are teratogenic. The aPTT is not useful for monitoring the effects of LMW heparins.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 665.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not have a direct bronchodilator effect?
questions.solution:
Although extremely important in severe chronic asthma and status asthmaticus, corticosteroids do not have a demonstrable direct bronchodilator action.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 249.

questions.text: A patient on PDE5 inhibitor therapy reports that the last dose was taken around 24 hours ago. You are planning to start nitrate therapy in this patient for angina. Which of the following PDE5 inhibitor intake most likely requires a postponement of nitrate therapy to avoid drug interaction?
questions.solution:
The drug interaction between nitrates and PDE5 inhibitor exists for around 24 hours. But tadalafil being a long-acting agent, the drug interaction exists beyond 24 hours (up to 36 hours). If the above patient had taken tadalafil, the postponement of nitrate therapy and alternative anti-anginal medications can be considered. The combination of nitrates and PDE5 inhibitor has a synergisitic action on intracellular cGMP levels that can result in uninhibited vasodilation and a precipitous fall in blood pressure.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 328.

questions.text: Erythromycin is given in intestinal hypomotility because:
questions.solution:
Macrolides having structural similarity with motilins (substances which tend to increase upper GI motility), tend to increase GI muscle contraction by acting as agonists at motilin receptors.

Macrolide non-antibiotics (Used as motilin receptor agonists)

  1. Camicinal
  2. Mitamecinal

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 802.

questions.text: Sparfloxacin and astemizole can cause:
questions.solution:
Other drugs causing torsades de pointes (Dancing around a point)

Zip dance in GTA

Zip → Ziprasidone

Dance → Torsades de pointes

G → Grepafloxacin

T → Terfenadine

A → Astemizole



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 572.
